articles.headline: Democrats in a Fight to Define ‘Winner’
articles.snippet: Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are sometimes overstating their own advantage as they woo voters and superdelegates.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are sometimes overstating their own advantage as they woo voters and superdelegates.
articles.lead_paragraph: With the fight for the Democratic presidential nomination likely to go on for weeks or months, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are battling to define what it means to be winning  and, in some instances, they are overstating their own advantage and understating the gains of the other.

articles.headline: Risks of Anemia Drugs for Patients With Cancer to Get More Scrutiny
articles.snippet: An F.D.A. advisory committee will consider placing further limits on the use of the Amgen drugs Epogen and Aranesp and the Johnson & Johnson drug Procrit.
articles.abstract: An F.D.A. advisory committee will consider placing further limits on the use of the Amgen drugs Epogen and Aranesp and the Johnson & Johnson drug Procrit.
articles.lead_paragraph: With federal drug regulators planning another meeting on Thursday to weigh the safety of widely used anemia drugs, Dr. Athanasius Anagnostou resists any urge to say “I told you so.”

articles.headline: Tech’s Late Adopters Prefer the Tried and True
articles.snippet: Millions of people are reluctant to change their technology habits just for the sake of progress.
articles.abstract: Millions of people are reluctant to change their technology habits just for the sake of progress.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Every time he fired up his Netscape Web browser since mid-February, John Uribe was greeted with a message urging him to switch to one of Netscape’s two successors, Firefox or Flock.

articles.headline: High Finance Backfires on Alabama County
articles.snippet: Jefferson County is teetering on the brink of bankruptcy after a series of exotic bond deals. It’s an extreme case, but one with echoes across the country.
articles.abstract: Jefferson County is teetering on the brink of bankruptcy after a series of exotic bond deals. It’s an extreme case, but one with echoes across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  In 2002, a banker named Charles E. LeCroy arrived here with a novel pitch to ease taxpayers’ burden. Some Wall Street wizardry, he said, could lighten their load.
articles.byline: By Kyle Whitmire and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Dow Climbs 416.66 for Its Biggest Gain in Over 5 Years
articles.snippet: Stocks had their biggest one-day gain in five years after the Federal Reserve said it would step up its lending to ease strain on the dysfunctional money market.
articles.abstract: Stocks had their biggest one-day gain in five years after the Federal Reserve said it would step up its lending to ease strain on the dysfunctional money market.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks had their biggest one-day gain in five years Tuesday after the Federal Reserve announced that it would step up its lending to ease strain on the dysfunctional money market.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Fed Hopes to Ease Strain on Economic Activity
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve offered to let the biggest investment banks borrow up to $200 billion in Treasury securities, which sent stock prices soaring.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve offered to let the biggest investment banks borrow up to $200 billion in Treasury securities, which sent stock prices soaring.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Impelled to take extraordinary measures for the second time in less than a week, the Federal Reserve moved on Tuesday to subdue the deepening crisis in credit markets by stepping up as lender of last resort.

articles.headline: Chief of AOL’s Parent Is Open to Deal
articles.snippet: Jeffrey L. Bewkes said he was open to combining AOL with another firm, but some say he may be soft-pedaling larger troubles at AOL as the company works to reinvent itself.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey L. Bewkes said he was open to combining AOL with another firm, but some say he may be soft-pedaling larger troubles at AOL as the company works to reinvent itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: AOL, the company that introduced millions of people to the Internet, has tried to reinvent itself many times. The latest effort, like those before it, does not seem to be going well.
articles.byline: By Saul Hansell and Louise Story
